Nanomaterials are materials with one or more dimensions falling into the nano meter scale. The dramatic size shrinkage renders them new electronic, magnetic, optical, and thermoelectric properties, which are not achievable by their bulk counterparts. It is widely accepted that the quantum confinement of electrons within potential walls created by nanoscale struc tures is responsible for the novel proper ties associated with the various types of solidstate nanomaterials. One of the most successful examples is provided by semi conductor quantum dots (QDs) whose sizes are typically within several nano meters. With strong sizedependent spectral properties and narrow emis sion, QDs have achieved great success in applications such as biological imaging, catalysis, and sensing. More generally, substantial progress has been made to synthesize or fabricate nanomaterials using either topdown and bottomup methods, providing enormous opportu nities for tailoring their dimension, mor phology, and chemical composition with
nanometer precision. In addition, the advancement of charac terization techniques has clearly revealed the dependence of chemical and physical properties of solidstate nanomaterials on their structural details.
Responsive optical nanomaterials are materials that can dis play optical changes in response to external stimuli. Over the past three decades, many research efforts have been devoted to developing smart optical nanomaterials that can sense and actively respond to external physical and chemical per turbations. The mostly explored responsive optical systems are built based on photonic crystals (PCs), which are periodi cally arranged dielectric materials with widely tunable optical properties. Due to the constructive and destructive interference of light by the periodic microstructures, they can efficiently diffract light, with the wavelength determined by the dielectric constants of the constituents and their spatial arrangement.[1] Various smart optical materials could, therefore, be estab lished by incorporating stimuliresponsive components into the photonic crystal lattice to alter either the dielectric con stants or the lattice structures. With a better understanding of photon–matter interactions and the significant progress in microfabrication techniques, the photonic crystal struc tures, as well as optical manipulation methods, have been greatly diversified, leading to the successful development of many highperformance sensors, detectors, displays, etc. The advances in the synthesis of colloidal nanomaterials, beginning
Responsive optical nanomaterials that can sense and translate various external stimuli into optical signals, in the forms of observable changes in appearance and variations in spectral line shapes, are among the most active research topics in nanooptics. They are intensively exploited within the regimes of the four classic optical phenomena—diffraction in photonic crystals, absorption of plasmonic nanostructures, as well as color-switching systems, refraction of assembled birefringent nanostructures, and emission of photoluminescent nanomaterials and molecules. Herein, a comprehensive review of these research activities regarding the fundamental principles and practical strategies is provided. Starting with an overview of their substantial developments during the latest three decades, each subtopic discussion is led with fundamental theories that delineate the correlation between nanostructures and optical properties and the delicate research strategies are elaborated with specific attention focused on working principles and optical performances. The unique advantages and inherent limitations of each responsive optical nanoscale platform are summarized, accompanied by empirical criteria that should be met and perspectives on research opportunities where the developments of next-generation responsive optical nanomaterials might be directed.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Isaac Newton recognized the constituent spectral colors of white light in his study of prism refraction back to 1666. Five years later, the terminology “spectrum” was first raised with the Latin meaning of “appearance” to describe his optical experiments. Subsequently, it was found that many optical phenomena that feature spectral colors, such as absorption, refraction, diffrac tion, and emission, had different physical origins despite the similarity in their appearance. From that on, different physical and chemical processes were adopted to generate and manipu late light, which in turn boosted the development of modern optics. Even after several centuries, these principles still rule the discovery of new materials for regulating the light propa gation, though more efficiently by controlling light–matter interactions at scales comparable to the wavelength of light.

at the early 1990s, with morphological (e.g., rods, plates, cubes) and property (Janus nanoparticles) anisotropy also facilitate the fabrication of PCs with remarkable structure complexity and optical properties.[2] A similar scenario was staged within the regime of plasmonic nanomaterials that feature pronounced surface plasmonic resonance at a specific optical frequency and corresponding colors in their colloidal dispersion. Since the early research efforts in responsive plasmonics in the 1980s,[3] various stimuliresponsive mechanisms have been designed based on the dependence of photon–electron resonance on the size, shape, coupling state, and chemical surroundings of the plasmonic nanoparticles. The booming development of nanoscience and nanotechnology has also promoted the emergence of nanomaterialsbased smart systems including stimuliresponsive liquid crystals, photoluminescent and reflective colorswitching devices. The most intriguing char acteristic of these types of nanomaterials, also one significant difference from conventional ones, is that they can respond to external stimuli via optical outputs in controllable and on demand manners. By combing the impressive achievements in the colloidal synthesis and lithographic fabrication, responsive optical nanomaterials have had a broad impact on the research community as well as a subtle influence on the design of next generation nanomaterials. To date, several review articles have been published focusing on specific subtopics of responsive optical nanomaterials.[4] Over the past decade, however, these subtopics have been fused in such a rapid manner that several working principles and practical strategies have been devel oped into general approaches to designing responsive optical nanomaterials. In this context, an overview of the progress of responsive optical nanomaterials may provide a blueprint for the future design of smart nanomaterials.
Herein, we review the current research progress in the design and fabrication of responsive optical nanomaterials. We aim to provide an overview of both general design principles and specific techniques reported in the library of published literature. According to the mechanisms of the optical processes, we categorize our discussions into the following subtopics: responsive photonic crystals based on diffrac tion (Section 2), active plasmonics based on resonant absorp tion and scattering (Section 3), colorswitching nanosystems based on absorption (Section 4), tunable liquid crystals based on polarization (Section 5), and responsive photoluminescent nanomaterials based on emission (Section 6), as shown in Figure 1a. At the beginning of each section, the underlying fundamental principles and concepts are discussed to illus trate the correlation between the optical performance and the structural, orientational, and compositional parameters in materials design. Despite the distinct physical photon– phonon and photon–electron interactions in the four classic optical phenomena, similarities in the reported approaches toward responsive optical nanomaterials are extracted from the research works published in the recent three decades, which are summarized in Figure 1b. Typically, four primary param eters can be manipulated in designing responsive optical systems: i) chemical surrounding of the nanomaterials; ii) distance between optical nanocomponents or functional nano materials with optical molecules; iii) orientation of anisotropic nanostructures; and iv) the chemical and physical properties

In addition, optically responsive nanoscale platforms, characteristic of either peak shifts or intensity vari ations, are organized under the frame of six types of stimuli, which, more specifically, includes magnetic, electric, thermal, optical, mechanical, as well as chemical changes. At the end of this review, we summarize the achievements in the relevant research areas and offer our personal remarks on the existing challenges and opportunities in designing novel responsive optical nanomaterials.

sections.heading: 2.1. RPCs Based on Perturbation to Order
sections.text: In wave optics, an optical pathway can be tuned by either controlling the dynamic force equilibrium between adjacent nanoparticles in colloidal dispersion or the distance of periodic structures embedded in stimuliresponsive polymers. In addi tion to the magnitude of periodicity, the quality also plays a role in enabling an effective response to applied stimuli, which normally gives rise to intensity fluctuation instead of a shift in reflection peak position.

sections.heading: 2.1.1. Magnetic RPCs
sections.text:
There are two types of magnetic interactions that superpara magnetic nanoparticles experience in colloidal dispersion under the external magnetic field, the magnetic dipole–dipole interac tion between adjacent nanoparticles and coupling between the dipole with the field. In the case of paramagnetic nanospheres with an induced magnetic moment of m, the associated mag netic field, exerting on another particle with separation of r, can be expressed as H = [3(m·r)r − m]/d3, where r is the unit vector pointing out from the center of the nanoparticle.[12] The coupling energy between the two dipoles is given by the
dot product of induced field and magnetization moment, U = m·H = (3cos2 θ − 1)m2/d3, where θ is the angle between the direction of induced magnetic moment and unit vector. The first derivative of this energy gives rise to the interparticle force

This equation predicts that the interparticle force is highly dependent on their relative orientation to the direction of the external magnetic field. It is attractive when θ∈ [0°, 54.74°] and repulsive otherwise. Compared with the kinetic energy associated with Brownian motion, the coupling between nano particles in the colloidal dispersion is around twoorders ofmagnitude stronger.[4d] For colloidal nanoparticles, the magnetic attraction may be balanced by longrange repulsions, such as electrostatic interactions, resulting in dynamic equilib rium and stabilization of chain structures. The first version of magnetically responsive photonic crystals was reported back in 1994,[13] where 1D chain structures were assembled from uni form emulsion droplets containing concentrated ferrofluids. This strategy, however, suffered from the poor stability of emulsion and limited compatibility.
In 2007, we prepared colloidal nanocrystal clusters (CNCs) of magnetite (Fe3O4) using a hightemperature hydrolysis reaction. The size of CNCs is tunable between 30 and 180 nm by simply controlling the hydrolysis kinetics. They are superparamagnetic due to the small size of the primary crystal units (≈10 nm), as shown in Figure 2a.[14] The substantial negative charges on the surface, rendered by the capping ligands, provide a strong electrostatic repulsive force to balance the dipole–dipole attrac tion.[15] Under an external magnetic field, they selfassemble into 1D nanochains with welldefined and tunable interparticle distance (Figure 2b).[4c] When the field was weak, uniform red color was observed in the colloidal dispersion due to the rela tively large interparticle distance. As the field strength increased

gradually, the digital images in Figure 2c showed continuously blueshift to final purple color. Such a color shift originated from a roughly linear correlation between interparticle distance and wavelength of reflected light (Figure 2d). This magnetic field responsive variation in distance shifts the reflection peak accord ingly, which is evidenced by the reflection spectra in Figure 2e. Directly applying this strategy to a system involving nonpolar organic solvents is problematic, since the surface charges are significantly suppressed. Further surface engineering was needed to overcome this barrier by, for example, the introduc tion of reverse micelles to promote charge separation.[16]
The dynamic equilibrium between forces of different phys ical origins could induce farreaching influences on the struc tural complexity as well as optical tunability of the assembled entities, especially under the scenario where the concentra tion of colloidal nanoparticles, as well as the strength of the external magnetic field, are so high that interchain interactions become effective. Phase transitions can be observed by assem bling CNCs in high concentration and strong magnetic field.[17] Under this scenario, the rearrangement between nanochains into zigzag multichains and further 2D planar photonic struc tures is energetically favored to occur.
Further increase in the colloidal concentration and strength of the magnetic field gives rise to a highcrystalline 3D phase.[18] Blueshift occurred on the assembled 3D photonic crystals by enhancing the strength of the magnetic field (Figure 3a–e). The corresponding phase transitions of photonic crystal struc tures were captured by smallangle Xray scattering, as shown in Figure 3f–i. Debye–Scherrer diffraction rings were observed without a magnetic field, indicating that CNCs selfassembled into nonclosepacked fcc structures with polycrystallinity gov erned by the dynamic interactions of hard steric repulsions, soft electrostatic repulsions, and van de Waals attractions. When further increasing the field strength, a transition to wellordered
singlecrystalline hexagonal structures was observed. The phase transition between the 2D hexagonal planer structures to a rather disordered 3D closepacked structures was reported at the top and bottom of a capillary containing the colloidal dis persion, respectively, due to the sedimentinduced concentra tion gradients.[19] Other types of crystal structures such as the bodycentered tetragonal (bct) phase were reported in magnetic assembled photonic crystals.[20]
The magnetic assembly and tuning strategy can be extended to packing nonmagnetic building blocks into RPCs by utilizing ferrofluids as the magnetic media.[21] Under the external mag netic field, as shown in Figure 4a, nonmagnetic particles such as polystyrene (PS) microbeads act as magnetic “holes,” whose induced magnetic moment is equal to the total moment of the replaced ferrofluids but with the opposite direction.[22] There fore, they experience magnetic interactions similar to the CNC case as shown in Figure 4b, and assemble from a random dispersion into 1D chains (observed in dark field as iso lated green spots) and then labyrinthlike 2D structures in an enhancing magnetic field (Figure 4d). When exposed to a strong magnetic field with high gradient, the PS beads become more concentrated locally over time due to the strong packing force and eventually form 3D photonic crystals with strong reflec tance up to 83% (Figure 4c). The timedependent enhancement of the reflectance is due to the increased particle concentration of PS beads, the overall thickness of the assembled film, and the improved longrange order of the 3D assemblies.
The magnetic field distribution of a ferrofluid can be further modulated by other nonmagnetic objects such as relief patterns, giving opportunities to further control the assembly behavior of the nonmagnetic particles.[21b] Figure 5a shows the simulated crosssectional magnetic field distribution around a polymer bump immersed in a magnetized ferrofluid, with the color bar indicating the relative strength of the local magnetic field. The

The nonmagnetic particles accumulate near the edge of the top surface and, as schematically shown in Figure 5b, they further assemble into chainlike structure due to the magnetic attraction. Figure 5c shows 1D nanochains of PS beads assembled around predesigned circular bumps that exhibit bright sizedependent structural colors.
One of the striking applications of magnetically responsive photonic crystals is color printing, which produces structural colors in the whole visible range. For example, the concept “Mink” was proposed in 2009 for structural color printing, which contained Fe3O4 CNCs and a photocurable resin.[23] As shown in Figure 6a, films with colors from red to blue were readily produced using the same Mink by increasing the strength of the magnetic field, which only show contrast changes under the transmission mode (Figure 6b). The color change was consistent with the response in reflection spectra in Figure 6c. When coupled with a focused UV beam that can be manipu lated using a digital micromirror array modulator, it is possible to print highresolution images with predesigned colors and patterns through a sequential color tuning and fixing process, as shown in Figure 6d. In addition to convenience (single ink), fast printing, and high resolution, the remarkable characteris tics of this Mink also include the ease of greyscale modulation and color mixing by mixing several spatially distributed dots

sections.heading: 2.1.2. Electrical RPCs
sections.text:
Under an electric field, colloidal nanoparticles with abundant surface charges experience longrange electric packing forces and tend to assembly into ordered structures when coupled with local electrostatic repulsion. This mechanism establishes a direct approach to electrical RPCs, which has been proved by tuning the dynamic equilibrium between those two forces on several types of colloidal nanoparticles, including silica,[25] poly styrene,[26] Fe3O4@SiO2,[27] ZnS@SiO2.[28] In addition, various types of elastomers were known to display electrochemical or physical phase transitions, such as the reorientation of polar phases, and matrix deformation originated from the coulombic interactions between charged groups or electricfielddriven
Adv. Mater. 2019, 1807061
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1807061 (8 of 33)
redox reactions.[29] These deformations are transcribed into the variations in the periodicity of the photonic structures including opals, inverse opals, and stacking layered films. Elas tomers inert to an electric field can also be used to construct electrical RPCs by coupling with an electroactive component. For example, thermosensitive liquid crystal inverse opal films were developed with their optical diffraction responsive to the electric field. This was achieved by adding an electrothermal conversion layer (graphite) between the electrodes, which induced a phase transition of liquid crystals (LCs) by the elec trothermal effect.[30] However, the multiple transitions signifi cantly damp the electrooptical signal processing, resulting in slow response rate, narrow diffraction tunability, high driving voltage. In this subtopic, we discuss several research attempts in engineering electrically driven RPCs with advanced elec trooptical transitions.
Block copolymer photonic gels consisting of alternating glassy PS and swellable poly(2vinyl pyridine) (P2VP) layers were employed for constructing electronic RPCs. The functional pyridine groups in the P2VP block are positively charged due to protonation, and the strong electrostatic repulsion expands the polymer matrix upon the application of a voltage on the anode. Experimentally, continuous redshift was observed against applied voltages.[31] To enhance the response and sensitivity, the pyridine was ionized by acids.[32] For example, quaternization of pyridine improved the response to subseconds, 1000 times faster than that of the PCs made of PSbP2VP without qua ternization. Under this scenario, the swelling of the polymer was not solely determined by the electrostatic interactions but
also the screening of ionized species, which overall gave rise to a monotonical decrease in the correlation between the wave length and the applied voltages, notably opposite to their initial versions.[32]
Another promising approach involves embedding colloidal crystals into an electrically responsive polymer matrix. In 2007, Ozin and coworkers developed photonic crystal fullcolor dis plays that could be actuated by an electric field.[33] Silica spheres were deposited onto an indium tin oxide (ITO) by convective selfassembly,[34] and then polyferrocenylsilane (PFS) was infil trated followed by polymerization (Figure 7a).[35] The working principle was based on the electrochemical redox reaction of PFS networks associated with the partial electronic delocaliza tion along the polymer backbone. Under oxidative (positive) potential, electrons of iron atoms were drawn out of PFS and anions from electrolyte were driven into the matrix to neu tralize the positively charged buildup (Figure 7b). The mass transfer of ions and solvents swelled the polymer matrix and hence pushed apart the silica layers, resulting in the redshift of diffraction peaks. Reversal transition was observed under reducing potentials. Notably, such an expansion in crystal lattice occurred mainly along the substrate surface normal owing to the covalent anchoring of the composite. As shown in Figure 7c, the peak shifted from 510 to 620 nm when the applied voltage increased. This strategy exhibited both high reversibility without noticeable degradation of optical diffraction after 1000 cycles and enhanced electrical bistability. Relying on ITO microstrip arrays, color (covering visible to nearinfrared) of each unit cell could be tuned individually by voltage with
Adv. Mater. 2019, 1807061
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1807061 (9 of 33)
considerable resolution and high color contrast (Figure 7d). However, the closepacked structure and dense polymer matrix slowed down the mass transfer considerably during an electro chemical process, resulting in sluggish response and the need for a high driving voltage. Two years later, the same group dis covered that removing the colloidal particles may result in an inverse opal structure with a high porosity, which may facilitate the electrolyte migration and lead to enhanced switching rate and lower driving voltage.[36]
By taking advantage of the electrophoretic effect of nanoparticles carrying considerable surface charges, one can dynamically tune the interparticle distance and the optical dif fraction by controlling the applied voltages.[26a] This strategy has been demonstrated in not only crystalline colloidal arrays (CCAs) featuring a global longrange order[25] but also amor phous photonic crystals with only a shortrange order.[27] Recently, Ge and coworkers reported electrical RPCs based on the CCAs assembled from supersaturated SiO2 dispersions.[25] As depicted in Figure 7e, negatively charged SiO2 spheres migrate to the anode by the electrostatic attractions while the order of CCAs was maintained by interparticle electrostatic repulsion, which results in shrinkage in periodicity. This structural evolution was evidenced by blueshift of diffraction peaks when the voltage was increased to 3.0 V (Figure 7f,g). To make this approach universal, researchers have devel oped several standard procedures to enhance the surface charges of colloidal nanoparticles, such as coating SiO2 on ZnS (from −5 to −48 mV)[28] and sulfonation of polystyrene (≈−50 mV after sulfonation).[26b] Similar electrooptical transi tions were also observed in quasiamorphous colloidal structures with comparable optical tunability and intensity.[27]

sections.heading: 2.1.3. Mechanical RPCs
sections.text:
The mechanical RPCs are most invariably composite struc tures fabricated either by assembling and fixing the photonic structures within the polymer matrix or by infiltrating polymer precursors into preassembled photonic structures followed by polymerization. Upon mechanical perturbation, the elastic defor mation alters the periodicity of embedded photonic structures and hence results in structural color changes as well as peak shifts. Generally, the polymers involved here are transparent and mechanically stable. More importantly, their mechanical proper ties determine the sensitivity of mechanical sensors, which are frequently modified by the polymer compositions, the degree of crosslinking, the volume ratio of guest materials, and so forth.
The assemblyfixation strategy has been widely reported for constructing mechanical RPCs. For example, a polyacrylamide (PAM) hydrogel film consisting of PS photonic crystals exhib ited a blueshift from 573 to 538 nm upon stretching along the lateral directions.[9] For enhancing the optical performance, the surface charge or solvation layer induced selfassembly was recently carried out in a more elastic polymer, poly(ethylene glycol) phenyl ether acrylate. The reflection peak of this com posite film continuously blueshifted from 618 to 485 nm when the lateral strain increased from 0 to 68.7% (Figure 8a). Since this reflection peak shift covered most of the visible range, an evident color change from red to green, and blue was observed
(Figure 8b). The high sensitivity and enhanced optical perfor mance were also evidenced by the significant color changes under local pressure within hundreds of micrometers.[37] Following the same working principles, the embedded photonic crystals could be easily etched chemically, generating inverse opal polymer films that were mechanical responsive.[11]

Photonic films that were sensitive to stretching, squeezing, pressing, and bending were developed by fixing the CCAs in poly(ethylene glycol) diacrylate (PEGDA).[38] Figure 8c showed dramatic peak shift during different mechanical processes. Despite high reversibility and tunable sensitivity, mechanical RPCs based on CCAs suffered from the apparent color varia tion in the polymer matrix owing to the presence of crystal domains. 1D chainlike structures, which were formed by the magnetic assembly of carbon coated Fe3O4 nanoparticles and fixed in PAM hydrogel films, were then reported with uniform colors and smooth color transitions upon mechanical stress.[39] Instead of this assemblyfixation process, an indirect approach was frequently reported as well by first assembling CCAs and then filtrating polymer precursors.[40] The advantages of this strategy over the former one are the easy availability of CCAs, making the fabrication process general for systems with a wide variation in the composition and surface properties of building blocks and drive forces of assembly. Also, the quality of closepacked CCAs has been dramatically improved in the last decades, and various advanced approaches toward large scale crackfree CCAs have been reported.[41] However, applying those techniques to the fabrication of highquality mechanical RPCs still calls for continuous research efforts.
Ultrasensitive RPC to mechanical perturbation was reported by Ge and coworkers in the systematical study of the crystal lization of SiO2 nanoparticles into metastable CCAs by super saturation induced precipitation.[42] Two typical phases were found, the crystal phase with orderly stacked nanoparticles, driven by longrange attraction and electrostatic repulsion, and a liquid phase with randomly dispersed nanoparticles. The sat urated SiO2 dispersion selfassembled within ≈2 min to reach the reflection maximum but disassembled within seconds by any tiny mechanical perturbations (e.g., agitation, flow, convec tion, and vibration). This saturation induced selfassembly was not limited to specific types of solvents.
Mechanical RPC without involving colloidal assembly was fur ther developed in 2014. An anisotropic photonic hydrogel was fab ricated by alternative stacking of rigid polymerizeddodecyl glyc eryl itaconate (DGI) bilayer domains in the soft, chemically cross linked PAM hydrogel.[43] DGI selfassembles into bilayers (≈5 nm) in the liquid phase, which further stack periodically into lamellar liquid crystals. Under the help of shear flow before polymeriza tion, their orientation was regulated along unidirectional align ment within the hydrogel film.[44] The CC double bonds of DGI made it possible to crosslink to the backbones of PAM through radical polymerization and enhance the mechanical properties. The synthesized platelike bulk hydrogel contained about 4000 polymericDGI (PDGI) bilayers and featured noticeable structural colors as well as anisotropic swelling and mechanical responses. Under lateral stress, a maximum 185 nm shift of reflection peak was reported and accompanied by obvious color changes in the hydrogel films. Although this process was reversible, it, unfortu nately, took more than 10 min to recover due to the strong vis coelasticity of hydrophobic association within PDGI bilayers.[45] Later, the response was improved to ≈15 s by further infiltration of PAM networks.[46] In 2014, one approach was proposed by split ting the rigid, continuous PDGI bilayers into small domains by anisotropic swelling. A timeresolution of several milliseconds was demonstrated for the color changes upon pulsed pressure.[47]

sections.heading: 2.1.4. Chemical RPCs
sections.text:
Generally, chemical RPCs based on periodicity are realized by swelling and shrinking of the polymer matrix in response to stimuli of chemical species, which are driven by osmotic pres sure and specific chemical bonding between photonic sub strates and chemicals, e.g., ions, solvents,[48] biomolecules,[49] and vapors.[50] The first version of ion sensor based on photonic structures was reported in 1997.[51] CCAs of PS spheres were trapped within the hydrogel matrix, where crown ether, capable of complexing Pb2+, Ba2+, and K+,[52] was copolymerized. The migration of counterions toward crown ether gave rise to Donnan potential and increased osmotic pressure within the hydrogel, which simultaneously swelled it and redshifted the reflection peak. By copolymerization of acrylates and acrylic acid, an inverse opal was fabricated against CCAs, which dis played similar swellinginduced peak shifts as carboxyl groups ionize under high pH.[53] This strategy was later extended to other ions by adopting corresponding recognizing groups, e.g., 4vinylbenzo18crown6 for K+,[54] 8hydroxyquinoline for Cu2+, Co2+, Ni2+, and Zn2+,[55] aptamers for Hg2+, Ag+, Pb2+,[56] and amide for SCN−.[57] In addition, concentration gradientdriven diffusion[58] and ion exchange[59] were reported as well to swell polymer matrices and induce optical peak shifts.
Ge and coworkers recently pointed out the importance of the evolution profile of the reflection band as a critical param eter when chemical RPCs are used as sensors.[60] As shown in Figure 9a, compared with static reflection spectrum, dynamic reflection spectra (DRS) consider the dependence of diffu sion on time and therefore can provide abundant information about the chemical and physical properties of the involved sol vents. The photonic crystal gels were prepared by fixing the metastable CCAs of SiO2 in poly(ethylene glycol) methacrylate (PEGMA), which were swollen by ethylene glycol. Relying on the polarity differences of homologous alcohols, ethanol, pro panol, butanol, and pentanol were readily distinguished by dif ferent DRS patterns. Generally, alcohols with stronger polarity (the one with shorter chains) diffuse faster into the gels, which appear as a sharper rise and earlier merging points in the DRS patterns (Figure 9b). Other physical properties such as viscosity, refractive index, and affinity to the gel also significantly affect the DRS patterns. Overall, the “similarity–intermiscibility” theory determines the optical response of chemical RPCs to various solvents.[61] The strategy of solventinduced swelling of hydrogel has also been studied for the fabrication of photonic papers[62] and reversible color printing,[63] by using environ mentfriendly solvents, such as water, ethanol, or salt solutions as the inks. Such chemical RPCs can also be used as humidity sensors,[64] which operate based on the dependence of the swelling of hydrogels on the humidity of the surroundings.[65]
The osmotic pressure represents a reliable force to assemble 3D photonic crystals with tunable bandgaps.[66] Hydrophilic PS beads were encapsulated within monodispersed doubleemul sion droplets. When dispersed in a salt (NaCl) solution, the high osmotic pressure could shrink the capsule isotropically and concentrate the PS beads inside. By controlling the osmotic pressure and incubation time, the color of each droplet dis played sequential progress from initial white to red, green, and finally blue. As the color blueshifted, the brightness, as well as

the peak intensity of reflection, increased dramatically due to a phase transition from shortrange to longrange order.[67] The fcc lattice structures were observed with the (111) plane aligned along the wall of capsules.[68] To overcome the uneven color dis tribution within the capsule due to the presence of local crystal line domains, noniridescent structural color covering the whole visible range was achieved based on the coherent scattering of dense amorphous packing of PS beads.[69]

sections.heading: 2.1.5. Thermal RPCs
sections.text:
Thermal RPCs are materials whose photonic bandgaps vary continuously and reversibly upon temperature changes. Several polymers and liquid crystal molecules are well known for their heatinduced phase transitions and the associated swelling– deswelling behaviors. Among those, the reversible hydrophilic swollen configuration to hydrophobic collapsed configura tion around the lower critical solution temperature (LCST) of poly(Nisopropylacrylamide) (PNIPAM) was first introduced by Asher and coworkers in the fabrication of thermal RPCs.[70] The hydrogel was swollen by water below 32 °C, leading to redshift in the diffraction of the embedded CCAs of PS beads. Revers ible switching between 704 and 460 nm was achieved by simply increasing and decreasing the temperature accordingly. Further studies revealed that sensitivity and tunability were control lable by the crosslinking degree of the PNIPAM gels.[71] CCAs assembled from PNIPAM colloids, however, showed remark able intensity change instead of peak shift.[72] By grafting cross linking groups to the backbone of PNIPAM, the order could be maintained during the phase transition.[73] If colloidal crys tals of PNIPAM microgels were crosslinked by photoinitiated polymerization of surface vinyl groups,[74] continuous blueshift
from 700 to 400 nm was observed (Figure 9c,d). In addition to bulk gel film, PNIPAM can be made into thermal RPC micro spheres by photoinitiated polymerization of emulsion droplets containing magnetically assembled 1D chains of magnetic CNCs.[75]
Instead of pure PNIPAM phase, additional functional poly mers are often incorporated into the hydrogel matrix to rendered the photonic gels sensitive to multiple stimuli.[76] For example, photonic electrolyte hydrogels were reported to respond to not only temperature but also pH by copolymerization of meth acrylic acid (MAA) with PNIPAM. By increasing the pH above the pKa of MAA, the carboxylic acid groups ionized, resulting in increased electrostatic repulsion within the gels and subse quently the swelling of the gel matrix. By altering the pH of elec trolyte in electrochemical reactions, Ueno et al. demonstrated fast (within minutes) and reversible switching between arbi trary diffraction states using copolymer gels fixed on anodes.[76a] Multiplestimuli responsive photonic gel was also reported by copolymerization of NIPA with 4acryloylaminoazobenzene.[77] This gel responded to both light and temperature change due to the photoisomerization of the azobenzene group. Wei and coworkers reported inverse opal photonic films composed of a liquid crystal elastomer by templating against the CCAs of silica.[78] When heating the film from 30 to 140 °C, the diffrac tion peak redshifted from 515 to 565 nm accordingly owing to the thermally induced orientation changes of liquid molecules and the subsequent macroscopic deformation of the film.

sections.heading: 2.1.6. Optical RPCs
sections.text:
The responsive units in optical RPCs are commonly photo chromic molecules, which are either grafted or copolymerized

© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1807061 (12 of 33)
into the photonic polymer matrices. Azobenzene and its derivatives are well known for cis–trans transitions upon light stimuli.[79] By copolymerizing the azobenzenedrafted monomers into the PNIPAM inverse opal, one could switch reversibly the diffraction between two states using light.[77] Irra diated by UV light, azobenzene existed in a cis configuration with a dipole moment, which expanded the polymer matrix due to the absorption of water and switched diffraction to 640 nm. Under visible light, however, it transformed into trans config uration with zero net dipole moment, and the gel relaxed to its initial state with the diffraction peak at 575 nm emerging gradually. A similar strategy was also reported by taking advan tage of photochemical electron transfer within small molecules (e.g., ringopening reactions), such as malachite green carbinol base (MG),[80] rhodamine B methacrylamide,[81] and spiroben zopyran.[82] Interestingly, instead of peak shift, photoioniza tion of MG gives rise to dramatic intensity fluctuation under the light. MG as a neutral molecule ionizes into two charged fragments, MG+ and OH− under UV light of 300 nm. The gen erated free ions screen the interparticle electrostatic repulsion and thereafter degrade the order as well as the diffraction peak intensity by forming point defects, vacancies, and grain bounda ries. The order can be recovered by stopping light irradiation.[83]

sections.heading: 2.2. RPCs Based on Perturbation to Refractive Index
sections.text: Tuning refractive indices of the components is another effi cient way toward stimuliresponsive photonic crystals, since small variances can induce substantial changes in the effective optical pathway. This strategy is generally achieved by mass transfer between chemicals with different refractive indices or phase transitions induced by electrochemical and photochem ical processes. Taking the dielectric mirrors as an example, the adsorption of chemical vapors within the pores of solid colloids or polymer matrices can alter the refractive index and hence shift the photonic stop bands.[84] From the sensor point of view, structures with higher porosity and open voids are more desir able, since they can not only enhance the mass transfer but also provide substantial space to absorb targeting chemicals. Another reliable way to build such a responsive system is by deposition of alternating layers of nanoparticles of materials with different refractive indices. The asproduced Bragg stacks, typically demonstrated using SiO2 and TiO2 layers, redshift in diffraction when exposed to solvent vapors.[84]

sections.heading: 2.2.1. Chemical RPCs
sections.text:
Inverse opals have been intensively studied for constructing RPCs sensitive to changes of refractive indices owing to their intrinsic advantages, such as high porosity, large free space, and interfacial areas.[85] Diverse materials could be used to construct the 3D skeleton, varying from metals,[86] to semi conductors,[87] oxides,[88] carbon materials,[89] salts,[90] and polymers.[91] For example, by using a group of solvents with a range of refractive indices, linear redshift with ≈370 nm per refractive index unit was observed in the inverse opal made of SiO2, ZrO2, and Al2O3.[92] Since the solvent infiltration is highly
dependent on their wettability to the 3D interfaces, the optical response of RPCs in principle can be modified by the surface treatment or modification. Based on this, chemical encoding was reported by treating the silica inverse opal alternatively by alkylchlorosilane vapors and oxygen plasma on the selected areas.[93] By varying the functional groups of alkylchlorosilane, the wettability of the selected areas of inverse opal was finely tuned, exhibiting predefined patterns when submerged in eth anol of different concentrations.[94] Another type of promising application of RPCs based on inverse opals was a chemical sensor. By infiltrating TiO2 inverse opal with poly aniline (PANI), reversible red and blueshifts were achieved once exposed to NH3 and HCl vapors respectively. PANI was in the form of emeraldine salt under acidic condition but converted into emeraldine base upon exposure to basic vapors owing to the reorganization of electronic structures. Consequently, the refractive index increased, giving rise to redshift of diffraction peaks.[95] The response rate could be significantly improved in the case of pure opal structures thanks to the enhanced mass transfer and easy accessibility of active sites. With the specific interactions between metal–organic frameworks and guest molecules, inverse opal made by Cu3(BTC)2 (BTC = benzenet ricarboxylate) was found to respond to various solvent vapors within 30 s. Their reversible optical responses were not in a similar manner though: redshift for cyclohexane and toluene, and blueshift for ethanol and acetone, depending highly on the physicochemical properties of target molecules. The detec tion limit was 10 ppm with a signaltonoise ratio of 50.[96] In the case of hydrogel inverse opal beads, the detection limits were reported down to 1 × 10−9 m for DNA[97] and 1 ng mL−1 for proteins,[98] both of which exhibited ≈2 nm shift in dif fraction peaks but with the opposite trends.[99] The changes of the refractive index of the 3D skeleton were also achieved by a photochemical process of ZnO inverse opal.[100] A change of up to 40% of transmission was reported upon UV irradiation, owing to desorption of O2 from the skeleton and associated decrease in refractive index.

sections.heading: 2.2.2. Electrical RPCs
sections.text:
The phase transitions of LCs were taken advantage of for engineering RPCs based on perturbation to refractive indices. By infiltrating liquid crystal molecules into the voids of CCAs, a 5.5 nm shift toward the shorter wavelength was reported under a voltage of 160 V.[101] The blueshift was induced by the decrease of refractive index from an averaged value of 1.584 to the 1.522 when LC molecules transited from random orien tation to parallel with the direction of the electric field. Later, more than 30 nm blueshift was realized on the same LC mole cules under similar electric voltages by hosting them in highly porous inverse opals,[102] due to a higher filling ratio of LC molecules than conventional opals.
Chemical reactions driven by electrical voltages are also capable of switching the refractive indices of components in photonic structures. Under positive electrical bias, the redox reaction of electrochromic tungsten trioxide (WO3) and nickel oxide (NiO) transform from their oxidized state to reduced one through the following electrochemical processes[103]

sections.heading: 2.2.3. Thermal RPCs
sections.text: Photo, thermo, or electrochemical processes that exert phase transitions with associated permittivity changes of the constitu ents of photonic structures found the basis for RPCs sensitive to light, temperature, or electric field. One overwhelming advantage of those chemical process is ultrahigh response rate, less than 10−12 s as reported in the structural phase transition of VO2 upon pulsed laser irradiation.[105] The phase transi tion at ≈67 °C was accomplished by changes in the real part of the refractive index from 2.9 in the “cold” semiconductor phase to 2.3 in the “hot” metallic phase.[106] By chemical bath deposition, VO2 was impregnated in the voids of SiO2 opals, and about 21 nm blueshift was observed under pulsed laser at 800 nm within a few hundreds of picosecond.[107] Jeong and Xia reported thermal RPCs based on the phase transition of monodispersed colloids consisting of aSe cores and βAg2Se shells that were produced by polyol process.[108] Whereas the Se core transited from amorphous to trigonal phase at 31 °C, Ag2Se had a phase transition from β to α at 133 °C. As a result, the packed opal crystals redshifted their photonic stopband at the NIR regions once increased the temperature to 150 °C due to the increase in the refractive indices of both shells and cores. The reversible shift in diffraction peaks induced by phase transitions fitted well with the effective refractive index theorem without any compensation in periodicity.

sections.heading: 2.3. RPCs Based on Orientational Tuning
sections.text:
Majority of photonic crystals, excluding the amorphous ones, exhibit viewingangle dependent structural colors due to the relevant variance in the effective optical pathway. These phe nomena have been developed into reliable strategies for RPCs by controlling the orientations of anisotropic building blocks or photonic crystals. In wave optics, the coherent correlation between Bragg diffraction and angles of light of being inter fered relative to the crystal orientation is highly dependent on the anisotropy of building blocks and symmetry of crystal struc tures. In the case of the 2D lattice of nanospheres, the band diagram is symmetric but has optical pathwaydependent band gaps across the visible ranges, which implies that their optical diffraction varies accordingly, as the orientation of photonic crystal structures is controlled by external stimuli. In the case
of nanoellipsoids, however, the shape anisotropy of building blocks breaks band symmetry along the “Γ” point. The sym metrybreaking provides additional freedom for tailoring the dynamic light interference by controlling the orientation of building blocks.
Tuning the orientation of photonic structures for RPCs can be best fulfilled in the case of 1D photonic nanochains that are magnetically assembled from CNCs (Fe3O4@SiO2). As dis cussed in Section 2.1.1, the orientation of nanochains is not random but features parallel alignment along the direction of the external magnetic field to minimize the anisotropic mag netic energy. Therefore, the photonic nanochains exhibited spe cific alignment by local field direction in a linear Halbach array, which generated alternately vertical and horizontal field on the surface. A bright structural color was observed in the vertical regions and significantly decayed to the parallel regions owing to the presence of high orientation gradients. Accomplished was the slightly blueshift as the Bragg angle decreased during the transition.[109] Ge et al. developed various types of magnetic RPCs relying on controlling the orientation of embedded nano chains. Magnetochromatic microspheres were fabricated by fixing the 1D nanochains inside the emulsion droplets of UV curable resin with the help of a magnetic field (Figure 10a).[110] The scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images in Figure 10b confirmed the chainlike periodic structures inside the micro spheres. Varying the orientation of microspheres through an external magnet, the diffraction shifted accordingly. In Figure 10c,d, as the tilting angle decreased to negative values, the diffraction peaks continued blueshifting, and intensity significantly decreased. In addition to emulsion droplets, con tinuous solid films with differently orientated 1D nanochains were reported for θcontrast anticounterfeiting labels, where θ represents the tilting angle of chains. By selectively aligning 1D nanochains inside specific areas of films, they exhibited optical contrast both in the reflection and transmission modes.[111] By combining magnetic assembly with sol–gel process, 1D nano chains could also exist as freestanding photonic structures instead of being fixed inside the polymer matrix. The mag netically assembled 1D nanochains could be further stabilized by silica deposition using a sol–gel process (Figure 10e), pro ducing fixed singlestranded photonic nanochains with uni form periodicity (Figure 10f). In this case, the photonic diffrac tion was tuned between “on” and “off” states by varying the ori entation of the external magnetic field (Figure 10g).[112] Taking advantages of their long decay of the “on” states in viscous solu tions, the 1D photonic nanochains were used for fabricating rewritable photonic pads that allow freehanding writing using a magnetic pen (Figure 10h). The photonic patterns remained up to 10 min in viscous glycerol solutions,[113] which, if desired, could also be erased anytime by applying another external mag netic field for uses of multiple times.
The anisotropic shape of the building blocks provides addi tional freedom to not only regulate their assembly behavior by controlling the forces of similar magnitude yet distinct physical origins but also tailor the collective optical properties of the assembled entities. In the case of ellipsoidal γphased Fe2O3@SiO2 core–shell particles whose easy magnetization was along the long axis, they could selfassemble into wellorien tated photonic crystals under the help of a magnetic field. By

maintaining the field direction during convective selfassembly, 3D photonic crystals were formed with both orientational and positional orders after evaporating water,[114] producing strong but untunable diffraction colors. Using ferromagnetic Fe@ SiO2 nanoellipsoids (Figure 11a–c) as the anisotropic building blocks, a new class of magnetic RPCs was demonstrated by controlling the orientation of nanoellipsoids via external mag netic fields.[115] In a highly concentrated dispersion, these nanoellipsoids spontaneously selfassembled into facecentered orthorhombic (fco) lattices as driven by the interparticle elec trostatic repulsion. Contrary to the scenario in 1D magnetic nanochains, the optical diffraction was not affected signifi cantly by the field strength but highly dependent on the direc tion of the applied magnetic field (Figure 11d,e). As shown in Figure 11f, the diffraction peaks continuously blueshifted from ≈730 to ≈510 nm during varying the field from vertical to the horizontal direction, which was induced by the decrease in the effective optical pathway. When subjected to a complex magnetic field generated by a linear Halbach array, a rainbow pattern containing red, green, and blue stripes was displayed in response to the periodical distribution of field orientations (Figure 11g). The magnetic tuning was fast (within seconds) and entirely reversible.

sections.heading: 3. Responsive Plasmonic Nanomaterials
sections.text:
Plasmonic nanostructures are another class of important optical nanomaterials with the capability of modulating the propagation of light via surfaceplasmonresonance (SPR) induced absorption or scattering. SPR originates from the collective oscillation of conductive electrons within nano structures under excitation of the electromagnetic wave. Gen erally, SPR is either localized within the subwavelength scale (localized surface plasmon resonance, LSPR) or propagating along the surface of planar interfaces as surface plasmon polariton (SPP). The excited states of electrons relax to their ground states by transferring their oscillating energy into either the collective vibration of lattices as phonon through a photothermal effect or reemitting light as strong scattering. Despite the structural diversities of plasmonic nanomaterials and associated complex physical transitions of SPR, their lineshapes are mostly invariably the sum of spectral intensi ties from several independent resonances. Therefore, most spectra of plasmonic nanostructures are symmetric against the peak maximum. The asymmetric features, however, do exist in certain welldesigned plasmonic assembly, such as the Au fourmember rings[116] and sphere–rod nanohybrids,[117]
Adv. Mater. 2019, 1807061
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1807061 (15 of 33)
due to the constructive and destructive interferences between a narrow discrete resonance and a broad spectral profile, which creates unexpected minimum close to the initial maximum and is named as Fano resonance. During the last three decades, the basic science of plasmonic optics has been extensively studied, and the potential applications of plas monic nanostructures have been widely explored in many disciplines, including optics, catalysis, chemistry, biology, and medicine. In this subtopic, we summarize practical approaches toward responsive plasmonic nanostructures with a specific interest in color changes of metallic nanostructures under various external stimuli. To relate the optical properties of nanostructures to their structural details, we first discuss the fundamental concepts of plasmonics and then specify the experimental design for constructing responsive plasmonics. For detailed discussions of fundamental aspects of plas monics and the optical responses of various nanostructures, we refer the readers to a recent review focused on active plasmonics.[4b]
It is wellestablished that the photon–electron coupling is dependent on the dielectric function and conductive electron distribution of nanostructures, through the variation in shape, size, morphology, and chemical compositions, as well as their surroundings.[118] Therefore, many efforts have been exerted on tailoring the optical properties of plasmonic nanostruc tures by synthetically controlling their sizes and morphologies
with nanometer precision. Tuning the dielectric surroundings of plasmonic nanostructures, including the solvent, capping ligands, and coating materials, was first proposed as a prom ising approach toward responsive plasmonic nanostructures. Though the line shape of plasmonic structures bears similarity of spectral maximum, they can originate from different reso nance modes, such as the transverse and longitudinal modes of metallic nanorods,[119] multipoles of large Au nanospheres[120] and coupling effect between individual resonances.[121] Accord ingly, active manipulation of the separation between plasmonic nanostructures and orientation of anisotropic metallic nano materials, together with control over the dielectric surround ings, has been utilized to induce changes in their spectral profiles and perceived colors and creates new opportunities in various fields such as sensing, catalysis, and photoelectronic devices.
Here we first discuss the analytical solution of Mie theory to characterize plasmonic resonance by extinction crosssec tion, which is basically the sum of absorption crosssection and scattering crosssection, and then define the overall profile of various plasmonic resonances. For a homogeneous dielectric surrounding with wavelengthindependent relative permit tivity, εm, the extinction crosssection of a metallic nanoparticle with considerably small size parameter, q(q = a/λ, where a is the radius of nanoparticles and λ is the wavelength of incident light), can be simplified as

This expression predicts a resonant spectral maximum when εm = 0.5[ε1 − (4ε12 + 3ε22)0.5], which can be deduced as εm = − 0.5ε1 considering the small imagi nary part of the relative permittivity, ε2. In the Drude model, this expression has a more efficient form, λLSPR = λP(2εm + 1)0.5, where λLSPR and λP are the resonant wavelengths of metallic nanoparticles and their bulk counterparts. Therefore, the res onant wavelength monotonically increases as a function of the relative permittivity of surroundings. A similar depend ence of longitudinal plasmonic resonance for anisotropic nanorods can be raised by prolate nanosphere approximation with the formula as λ′LSPR = λP[ε∞ + (1/P − 1)εm]0.5, where ε∞ is highfrequency relative permittivity of metal and P is shape dependent depolarization along the long axis of the nanorods. This equation suggests another type of responsive plasmonics that operates via perturbing the P term. Experimentally, this has been achieved by orientational control of nanorods using external stimuli such as magnetic or electric fields. The third type of responsive plasmonic nanostructures can be con structed if the dielectric properties of plasmonic nanostructures can be modulated by external stimuli including light and chem icals. According to the formula approximation of nanorods, the shift of resonant wavelength is predicted to be proportional to the change in the electron density according to the relation: Δλ = − λ′LSPRΔN/2N, where N is the electron density and ΔN its change in response to external stimuli.
Finally, the active interference between plasmonic resonance from neighboring particles can remarkably reconfigure the localized electric field distribution, hence induces unusual optical phenomena. The plasmonic coupling can either induce a significant shift in the resonance wavelength without affecting the intrinsic symmetry of the components or unexpectedly induce asymmetric spectral maximum and minimum by Fano resonance. The separationdependent coupling can first be inter preted as the dielectric effect of the surroundings, which induces remarkable spectral changes once the particles are close enough to “couple” with each other. However, the coupling induced spectral evolution depends not solely on separation but also on the morphology of nanostructures to be coupled, implying that this farreaching effect has deep physical origins. Therefore, a hybridization model was proposed to understand the coupling behaviors. Taking the dipolar coupling between Au nanospheres as an example, the interaction energy, given as V ∝ p1p2/r3 (p1, p2: magnitudes of dipole moment; r: interparticle distance) between two adjacent nanospheres is sufficiently strong to induce spec tral splitting of initial resonance into two: red and blueshifted ones corresponding to the bonding and antibonding hybridized modes. In the lowfrequency mode, the dipoles of the two Au nanospheres are aligned along the longitudinal direction and couple mutually, forming bright bonding mode in the far field. For highenergy resonance, the two initial dipoles are antia ligned and cancel out, resulting in zero net dipole moment and forming a dark antibonding resonance mode. Quantitative
studies have uncovered the roughly exponential dependence of plasmonic shift on interparticle distance as Δλ/λ = Ae−d/(sτ), where A is the maximum shift, d the edge–edge distance, and τ the decay length of the electric field.[122]

sections.heading: 3.1. Plasmonic Response to Surrounding Dielectrics
sections.text: Under plasmonic excitation, the conductive electrons diverge from the center, and consequently, trigger harmonic oscillation, which induces polarization changes in the adjacent medium. The charge density in medium with large εd is higher than the one with smaller εd if the magnitude of the localized electric field is similar. Under this scenario, plasmonic particles in a high ε medium will experience more reduction in the electrostatic potential of the excited harmonic oscillation and consequently lead to redshifted resonant frequency according to the corre lation between oscillatory frequency (ω) and potential (U) in a harmonic oscillation theorem, ω ∝U0.5. Such a response of plas monic resonance to the dielectric properties of surroundings has been widely observed in various types of nanostructures under diverse extremal stimuli, such as optical, electric, and magnetic fields, chemical or electrochemical processes, and heat. On the other hand, the ability of plasmonic nanostructures to respond to changes in dielectric properties (e.g., refractive index) varies significantly on their size and morphologies. Prac tically, it is characterized by the wavelength shift per refractive index unit (RIU): S = Δλ/Δn in nm RIU−1. Materials showing large shifts upon changes in refractive index share similar fea tures, such as having sharp tips or abnormal spectral profiles. For example, S is 150–540 nm RIU−1 for gold bipyramids[123] and approaches ≈700 nm RIU−1 for Au nanobranches,[124] which are much higher than Au nanospheres[125] (40–90 nm RIU−1) or nanorods[125a] (200–290 nm RIU−1). Extreme cases include Au mushroom arrays[126] with S up to 1050 nm RIU−1 and Fano resonance with S up to ≈1200 nm RIU−1.[127]

sections.heading: 3.1.1. Optically Responsive Plasmonic Nanomaterials
sections.text:
Optically sensitive plasmonic nanostructures are usu ally achieved by incorporating plasmonic nanostructures into photochromic molecules, which can switch between two thermodynamically stable states through photochem ical reactions. Photochromic molecules and photochemical reactions commonly involved in responsive plasmonics include cis–trans isomerization (azobenzene),[128] photo cyclization (diarylethene),[129] intramolecular mass transfer, and dissociation. The first few experimental attempts were made in the 1990s,[130] when plasmonic films were coated by polymer doped with photochromic molecules. The reflection of multilayered films was then modulated by the UVinitiated absorption–transparency transition of photochromic molecules. However, tuning the extinction peaks of plasmonic nanostruc tures with welldefined morphology, like nanoprisms and nanorods,[131] had not been achieved until 2014. Azobenzene, a commonly used photochromic model molecule, was grafted to the surface of Au nanoplates through thiol chemistry,[128] which underwent cistotrans transition under blue light (450 nm) and
Adv. Mater. 2019, 1807061
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1807061 (17 of 33)
reverse transition under UV light. The LSPR of Au nanoprisms experienced ≈21 nm redshift from cis to trans configuration in solid state due to an increase of ≈0.5 nm in the height of molecules and associated dielectric change. The responsive interaction can also be achieved by embedding photochromic molecules into mesoporous silica layer on Au nanorods that are immobilized on substrates.[131] Reverse photocyclization occurred when exposed to UV and visible light alternatively. In its ringopening form, a clear splitting of longitudinal mode was observed if its resonance frequency was between the two absorption frequencies of photochromic molecules, forming a coupled hybridized state. Once the longitudinal mode was away from the two absorption bands, the photochromic molecules acted as a dielectric layer with a complex refractive index that changed accordingly during photocyclization and hence shifted the LSPR peak slightly.

sections.heading: 3.1.2. Thermally Responsive Plasmonic Nanomaterials
sections.text:
Thermally responsive plasmonic nanostructures are another type of active plasmonics, whose refractive index as well as spectral profile changes along with temperature. The working principles are mainly based on the temperaturedependent phase transitions of polymers, benzocyclobutene resins,[132] liquid crystals,[133] metals, and metal oxides. In the case of the thermosensitive polymer, the refractive index changes gradually with temperature due to the reconfiguration of polymer chains and the difference of packing density. PNIPAM is wellknown for its reversible phase transition from hydrophilic swollen con figuration to hydrophobic collapsed configuration around the LCST at ≈32 °C in water.[134] For example, a change of 0.06 in
refractive index and 10 nm redshift of extinction was reported on the PNIPAM grafted Au nanoarrays.[135]

sections.heading: 3.1.3. Chemically Responsive Plasmonic Nanomaterials
sections.text:
Similar peak shift was also observed in Au nanodisk array coated with bistable, redoxcontrollable [2]rotaxane mole cules.[136] A reversible plasmonic peak shift of ≈10 nm was achieved by a redox reaction of [2]rotaxane. This strategy is fea sible for various molecular machines with similar functionali ties and usually responsive to multiplestimuli, including light, electricity, and chemical reactions. Other types of chemical stimuli may include electrochemical processes,[137] humidity, protonation, ionic strength,[138] and specific reactions between biological molecules,[139] such as DNA, and redox reaction of metals.[140] As a semiconducting polymer, polyaniline (PANI) can show significant variations in its conductivity and the dielectric properties upon protondoping.[141] By coating Au nanorods with PANI, their scattering peaks can be revers ibly switched between 640 and 740 nm by simply protonating and deprotonating the PANI shell, respectively (Figure 12a). The chemical process of PANI switches not only the scattering peak position but also the intensity of the plasmonic response, as shown in Figure 12b,c. The scattering dots under the dark field optical microscope were red and brighter upon deproto nation. Figure 12d,e are the timedependent scattering spectra during deprotonation and protonation process. The plasmonic response approached maximum within several minutes.[142] By changing the shell materials to Pd, the plasmonic response of anisotropic Au nanostructures was reported to sense hydrogen. Pd nanostructures are considerably active in dissociation of
Adv. Mater. 2019, 1807061
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1807061 (18 of 33)
hydrogen molecules and can absorb hydrogen atoms to form palladium hydride. As the result of the corresponding change in the dielectric functions, a maximum redshift of ≈140 nm in plasmonic peaks was reported on (Au nanobipyramid core)@ (Pd shell) bimetallic nanostructures.[143] More precise control over the surrounding dielectrics was reported in the endonu clease activity of DNA. Au nanoparticles were modified with doublestranded DNA and acted as plasmonic ruler, which experienced a peak shift of 1.24 nm per DNA base pair.[144]

sections.heading: 3.2.1. Electrically Driven Orientational Control
sections.text:
Liquid crystals, featuring anisotropic optical properties, hold great promises toward responsive plasmonic nano structures.[148] The alignment of LC molecules in response to external stimuli, including electric and magnetic fields and temperature change, exerts macroscopic phase transi tions, which can be utilized to modulate the polarization of light or the orientation of anisotropic plasmonic nanostruc tures. In 2011,[149] the first LCbased active plasmonic device was achieved by modulating the longitudinal scattering of Au nanorods on the substrate. Under zero field, the orienta tion of liquid crystal molecules was parallel to the electrodes. A homogeneous to twisted nematic phase transition occurred under the external electric field, which orthogonally switched the polarization of the scattered light. As shown in Figure 13a, when the polarizer was parallel to the electrode, for the ran domly dispersed Au nanorods, the strongest scattering was observed on those parallel to the electrode due to the excitation
Adv. Mater. 2019, 1807061
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1807061 (19 of 33)
of their longitudinal plasmonic mode. By applying an electric voltage, the scattering signals were suppressed to a minimum (Figure 13b,c). This strategy also worked on SPP propagating on the periodic plasmonic surface but exerted polarization independent reflection and active plasmonic fullcolor tuna bility owning to the grating–SPP coupling. Later, more efficient approaches were developed by the assembly of anisotropic plas monic nanostructures in LCs, which exerted simultaneous and reversible response of collective plasmonic excitation to the external electric field instead of modulating the optical proper ties of an individual structure.[150] A nematic dispersion could be obtained using Au nanorods and nanoplates whose surfaces were passivated by poly(ethylene glycol), which imposed weak tangential boundary conditions owning to anisotropic surface interaction and realigned them parallel to the average local molecular orientations. Collective plasmonic excitation of Au nanorods responded continuously to the changes in the elec tric field (Figure 13d). In the extinction spectra (Figure 13e), the longitudinal mode was gradually suppressed by increasing the field magnitude. Consequently, the LC cell switched color from green, complementary color to the longitudinal absorp tion at 700 nm, to red, complementary color to the transverse absorption (Figure 13f,g).
