The associated demagneti zation energy can be simplified as 1 2 sindemag 0 2 2E mµ θ= (15) where µ0 is the permeability of free space and θ is the angle between the field direction and the long axis of ellipsoids.[4d] Basically, it predicts an energetically favored orienta tion when θ equals 0, which means an automatic parallel alignment. Relying on the high affinity between Au surface and amino groups, Au nanorods were attached to the surface of Fe3O4@SiO2 nanorods modified with aminosilane with parallel manner (Figure 14a).[152] The nanohybrids can be aligned along specific directions by an external magnetic field, which provided an opportunity for selective excitation of two
Adv. Mater. 2019, 1807061
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1807061 (20 of 33)
modes of Au nanorods. As shown in Figure 14b,c, only the longitudinal plasmonic resonance was observed when the field direction was parallel to the zaxis, and consequently, the colloidal dispersion was green. Gradually varying the field direction to yaxis suppressed the longitudinal mode instantly and instead enhanced transverse mode. A response of 200 Hz (in millisecond scale) with a 6% modulation to the laser inten sity at 650 nm was demonstrated. This strategy was later extended to modulate the scattering of Au microplates by attaching small γFe2O3 nanoparticles[153] Block nanocompos ites with integrated plasmonic and magnetic segments repre sent another type of magnetically responsive plasmonics, as demonstrated by block Ni–Au nanorods synthesized by elec trochemical deposition in porous alumina templates.[154] By controlling their orientations magnetically, the strongest scat tering peak shifted by more than 100 nm. During magnetic manipulation, however, irreversible aggregation of nanorods occurred due to the strong magnetic interaction and poor sur face modification, which degrades the optical performance. In addition, a combination of topdown lithography and bottom up assembly was reported to construct magnetic–plasmonic nanocomposites.[155] Particularly, Zn0.2Fe2.8O4 and Au nanocrystals were assembled in rodshaped templates. Subse quent ligand exchange by thiocyanate fuses Au nanocrystals together,[156] forming porous 3D networks with high mechan ical stability. The assembled nanorods with notable monodis persity (Figure 14d) exhibited a superparamagnetic response to an external magnetic field. In Figure 14e,f, the transmission at 2600 nm was modulated from 20% to 50% when the rods were realigned from parallel to perpendicular to polarization direction.

sections.heading: 3.3. Plasmonic Response by Controlling Coupling Distance
sections.text:
The strong dependence of plasmonic shift on interparticle separation provides an alternative mechanism for constructing responsive plasmonic nanostructures. Various types of active plasmonics responsive to physical or chemical stimuli have been developed by either direct assembly or perturbation of the assembled nanostructures in colloidal dispersion or solid matrices.[157] Metallic nanoparticles could be selfassembled into chain like structures in solution by regulating the electrostatic interactions, most of which responded reversibly to chemical stimuli, including ionic strength,[158] solvent effect,[159] pH,[160] and heat.[161] For example, negatively charged Au nanoparticles capped with bis(psulfonatophenyl)phenylphosphine (BSPP) were found to selfassemble into 1D nanochains (Figure 15a) by reducing the electrostatic interactions.[162] As shown in Figure 15b, a new plasmonic band emerged and kept red shifting while the intensity of the initial band located at 520 nm decreased if the ionic strength of the solution increased. The high surface charge of BSPP and its strong binding to the Au surface prevented the permanent connection between nano particles and rendered reversibility in assembly.[158,163] Ther moresponsive assembly and disassembly of Au nanoparticles were also observed.[161] By sweeping the temperature from 5 to 40 °C and then back to 5 °C, Au nanoparticle chains were disas sembled and then assembled. The thermoresponsive assembly and disassembly were driven by the temperaturedependent surface charge and hence interparticle electrostatic interactions. The assembled Au nanochains were later incorporated into polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) to produce a film that can
Adv. Mater. 2019, 1807061
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1807061 (21 of 33)
indicate pressure based on its color change.[164] As illustrated in Figure 15c, upon mechanical pressure, the initial dark blue color of the film turned into purple, deep red, and finally bright red due to the disassembly of Au nanochains. The absorption spectra in Figure 15d depicted the gradual blue shift and even tual disappearance of the coupling peak in response to different amounts of pressure.
The active plasmonic coupling can also be realized when metal nanoparticles are linked by stimulusresponsive molecules[165] or embedded into polymer matrices that can respond to stimuli.[166] Although their plasmonic coupling was responsive to heat[167] or pH,[166b] substantial variations in interparticle distance invariably induced broadband resonance. Reconfiguration or specific binding of molecules, especially those biological ones, provides precise control over the cou pling distance within several nanometers.[166a] For example, the separation between Au nanoparticles could be tuned to less than 1 nm if two separate chemical linkers were employed to anchor the hairpin DNA to nanoparticles.[168] Au dimers were also reported with reversible optical switching properties in the aptamerAu plasmonic ruler system for sensing single secreted molecule of live cells.[169] In addition, lightdriven proteins that can utilize light energy to induce conformational changes for biological functions are promising candidates toward responsive plasmonic nanostructures. Recently, a DNA derivative with similar light response was synthesized by modi fying DNA oligonucleotides with azobenzene. Relying on the trans–cis transition of azobenzene initiated by light, DNA ori gami templates can be reversibly tuned between locked and relaxed states. By assembling Au nanorods on each origami template, it was translated into a reversible chiroptical function with large amplitude modulation.[165b] One of the drawbacks in active plasmonics based on chemical reactions or mole cular configuration changes, however, is the low response rate due to their intrinsic kinetics of approaching thermodynamic equilibrium.
Electron tunneling describes a phenomenon in quantum mechanics where electron tunnels through the energy bar rier that it cannot surmount. The electron tunneling can be induced by applying an electrochemical potential[170] or shrinking the potential wall.[171] At subnanometer regime, the interference between individual resonance is so strong that new mechanism as quantum plasmonics dominates. As the interparticle distance falls into the subnanometer regime, the significant decrease in physical gap minifies the thickness of the energy barrier between the two potential wells and hence increases the transmission possibility of electrons. When tun neling conductance is enhanced to some extent, the electron distribution inside the coupled plasmonic nanostructures is reconfigured, which modifies the plasmonic resonance in optical frequencies. Controlling the tunneling conductance of electrons by bias voltage was proposed to actively tune the quantum effect of plasmonic coupling.[171a] Although this strategy has not been realized experimentally, several previous results showed hints toward practical active quantum plas monics. Back in 2000, electrons were found to tunnel into Ag nanoparticles in a working electrode during an electrochemical process. Plasmonic resonance blueshifted from 404 to 392 nm when ≈1790 electrons were doped into each Ag nanoparticle
(9.8 nm). A similar shift happened in the case of Au nanorods (≈11 nm) and nanoprisms (≈4 nm) as well under the same applied potential, both of which were consistent with the cor relation of Δλ and P.

sections.heading: 3.4. Self-Regulating Plasmonic Response
sections.text:
Selfregulating plasmonics undergoes optical transitions by perturbating their own electron density or distribution inde pendent of the dielectrics of surroundings. Several chemical or physical processes capable of causing considerably strong electron reconfiguration in plasmonic nanostructures include morphological reconstruction induced by lightpromoted dis solution–redeposition[172] or photothermal effect,[173] electron redistribution under laser excitation,[174] electron transfer between metallic nanoparticles and surface ligands.[175]
In addition to achieving various LSPR at a desirable fre quency by colloidal synthesis, morphological reconstruction is another reasonable option of tailoring the optical properties of plasmonic nanostructures. By exposing Ag nanoplates to UV light, a remarkable plasmonic peak shift was observed from 871 to 450 nm within 125 min, and the color of the colloidal dispersion changed gradually (Figure 16a–c). The morpholog ical reconstruction was confirmed by the transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images of nanoplates before and after UV irradiation, as shown in Figure 16d,e, respectively. Although anisotropic metallic nanostructures are stable in terms of kinetics, they are still not at thermodynamic equilibrium due to the presence of energetically unfavored sharp features. Under external stimuli, like UV irradiation or high temperature, con version to round shape occurs, which has been observed in the case of Au nanorods during laser irradiation.[176] Taking advan tage of continuously tunable spectra during the reconstruction of metallic nanostructures, plasmonic color laser printing was realized in 2016.[177] As shown in Figure 16f, the main SPR blueshifted and the printed color changed from cyan to yellow when the laser dosage increased. The conversion of nanodisks to nanoparticles was confirmed in Figure 16g. By increasing laser intensity, spheres were ablated from the polymer inter face owing to the rapid change in the center of mass during the melting process.[173] Each pixel could be printed in nano second time scale due to the instant photothermal conversion with overall resolution up to 127 000 DPI.
Laser is another powerful technique to manipulate the dis tribution of electrons by exciting the electric or vibrational state of plasmonic nanostructures out of equilibrium. Once excited by a pulsed laser, another probe laser is usually applied to monitor the changes in the optical properties. Under intense laser excitation, nonlinear interband excitation and heating of electrons occur, which consequently change the distribution of conductive electrons.[178] Recently, ultrafast switching of light polarization was realized in nonlinear anisotropic Au nanorod arrays.[179] Under the excitation of a control pulsed laser,[174a,180] ultrafast lightinduced variations of ordinary and extraordinary refractive indices were observed. The differences between the variations allowed active manipulation of the polarization of transmitted light by adjusting the intensity of control light. The ultrafast optical response was also realized on the modulation

of coupled plasmonic resonance of Au nanoparticles[181] and active control of SPP on bulk plasmonic materials.[182]

sections.heading: 4. Responsive Color-Switching Systems Based on Nanomaterials
4.1. Color-Switching Based on Physical and Chemical Transitions
4.1.1. Optically Responsive Color-Switching Nanomaterials
sections.text:
We carried out a systematic study of photocatalytic redox reactions of dyes based on TiO2 and the derivatives for color switching and rewritable papers.[183] Methylene blue (MB), for example, is a heterocyclic aromatic dye with bright blue color in its oxidized form, which can be switched to colorless leuco methylene blue (LMB) upon reduction (reduced form). Relying on the photocatalytic activity of TiO2, blue MB was transformed into colorless LMB upon UV irradiation while the photogenerated holes oxidized sacrificial electron donor (SED). By simply exposing to oxygen, the blue color recovered due to the oxidization of colorless LMB.[184] TiO2 nanocrystals with small sizes and low crystallinity were synthesized to achieve considerably low photocatalytic activity, which could not sub stantially degrade the chemical structure of MB but was suf ficiently strong to induce redox reactions. The transition from blue MB to colorless LMB occurred in 10 s by UV irradiation while the blue color recovered after 15 min irradiation of vis ible light. Compared with conventional color switching systems based on photoisomerization of chromophores, the photocata lytic color switching based on colloidal TiO2 nanocrystals was more environmentally friendly and promising in terms of high switch rate and good cycling performance. However, the long term photostability of LMB is not satisfactory due to consider ably quick oxidation by ambient oxygen. This drawback was overcome by adding hydroxyethylcellulose when preparing a solid film, which could not only chemically stabilize the LMB
from oxidation but also slow down the oxygen diffusion.[185] Remarkable enhancement was observed in the stability of reduced form as only ≈20% LMB was reoxidized within ≈6 days under ambient conditions. In contrast to the high stability, the recoloration rate could be enhanced by heating at 115 °C (Figure 17a,b). With the use of other dyes, a similar procedure was carried out to produce the other two primary colors: neutral red and acid green for red and green respectively (Figure 17c).
The porous fibrous network in soft papers physically sepa rates the dye molecules from TiO2 catalysts, which signifi cantly slows down the photochemical process and degrades the printing performance. As demonstrated in Figure 17d, printing on conventional papers could be achieved by replacing the molecular dyes with nanocrystals of solid pigments, like Prussian Blue (PB) nanoparticles and its analogues.[186] By simply changing the transition metals in the synthetic coor dination compounds, three primary colors were produced directly on conventional papers, KFe3+[Fe2+(CN)6] for blue, KCo2+[Co3+(CN)6] for red, and KCu2+[Co3+(CN)6] for green. Various types of oxygenvacancyabundant nanocatalysts have been used to power redox reaction for rewritable papers independent on external SEDs.[188] For example, the cycling per formance and optical response were promoted by photocatalytic color switching of the redox dyes based on Ba2+doped TiO2.[188] Chemical doping with metal ions of lower valence, like Ba, than Ti was reported as a reliable way to induce oxygen vacancies.[189] During writing, the photogenerated holes could be efficiently

Tungsten oxide (WO3) nanomaterials with electrochromic and photochromic response have been used for colorswitching, including smart windows and rewritable papers.[191] An optical switch between colorless and blue reversibly occurs owing to the photochemical reduction of W6+ to W5+. This phase tran sition can be powered by light or electric field through an “electron–proton double injection” mechanism.[192] Chen and coworkers engineered this optical switch into an organic–inor ganic hybrid film by electrospinning of PVP and amorphous WO3 nanofibers on regular papers.[193] Letters and patterns were printed by UV light within 10 s and maintained at ambient condition for more than 5 days. The oxidation of W5+ to colorless WO3, however, took more than 5 min even under ozone, making erasing information the limiting process in the writing–erasing cycles.

sections.heading: 4.1.2. Chemically Responsive Color-Switching Nanomaterials
sections.text: In the case of Pd decorated ZnO1−x nanorods, color switching was realized by reversibly catalyzing the hydrogenation and oxidative dehydrogenation of thionine. Under H2 atmosphere, blue thionine (TH+) was reduced to leuco thionine, exerting apparent color change in the solution, and reverse oxidation was instead triggered by exposure to O2.[194]

sections.heading: 4.1.3. Thermally Responsive Color-Switching Nanomaterials
sections.text:
Recently, the temperaturedependent phase transition of inor ganic halide perovskite was utilized for constructing color switching devices.[195] Halide perovskites have unique crystalli zation behavior: an inverse temperature crystallization process frequently modified by the halide constituents.[196] Gradually increasing temperature to 120 °C induced both compositional and structural phase transitions of halide perovskites. Accord ingly, the color of the solution changed from initially pale yellow to orange, red, and finally black. The forward and back ward color transitions were achieved by heating–cooling cycles. Later, switchable photovoltaic windows were proposed based on phase transitions of halide perovskites that transformed to opaque solar cells by heating over critical temperature and then turned transparent by exposure to water vapor or cooling.[197] Yang and coworkers demonstrated a thermochromic solar cell by taking advantages of structural phase transitions in
Adv. Mater. 2019, 1807061
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1807061 (24 of 33)
inorganic CsPbI3−xBrx films.[198] Upon heating, the transparent nonperovskite phase transformed into perovskite solar cells, which was further stabilized at room temperature for con tinuous power generation and operation. The backward phase transition would occur only by moisture exposure, resulting in a highly transparent film. The lower amount of Br ions in composition led to faster phase transition and more sensitivity to the moisture. Still, it needed several hours to reach phase equilibrium for both forward and backward transitions. Con siderably fast switching under the order of only a few min utes was reported by Neale and coworkers relying on the new understanding that solar photothermal heating was sufficient to power the dissociation of complexes of CH3NH3PbI3·xCH 3NH2,[199] which was associated with a transition from a trans parent film (68%) to a solar cell phase with low optical trans parency (less than 3%) during heating. Compared with existing smart window techniques, the new perovskitebased color switching systems provide more opportunities. For example, the maximum transparency in the CsPbI3−xBrx films was reported up to 82%, which was higher than that in thermo chromic, gasochromic, and liquid crystal platforms.[200] Most importantly, the feasible switch between transparent windows and photovoltaic devices provides a tunable balance between transparency and solar energy harvesting.

sections.heading: 5.1. Electrical LCs
sections.text: Conventional electrically driven LC cells were realized in the solvent dispersion of carbon nanotubes and graphene.[202] It was not achieved, however, until 2014 in the case of graphene oxide (GO) due to the dominant electrophoretic drift and elec trode reduction instead of liquid crystal ordering under an elec tric field.[203] Song and coworkers found the liquid crystallinity of GO under the flow or highfrequency alternatingcurrent electric fields.[204] The induced liquid crystalline phases of GO dispersion exhibited classic birefringent textures under low concentration due to the high aspect ratio and collapsed into an isotropic phase when the electric field was off.[205] Notably, the phase transition was slightly different from conventional LCs, which exhibited an orientational transition from surface induced spontaneous alignment to electrically ordering states. Taking advantages of larger polarizability anisotropy of GO and Onsager’s excludedvolume effect for LC ordering, the depend ence of the optical birefringence on the electric field was measured to be 1.8 × 10−15 mV−2 in terms of the Kerr coeffi cient, overwhelming the reported values of conventional LCs. Another promising feature of GO LCs was the relatively low power consumption for optical switching. The fabricated GO liquid crystal displays (LCDs) could work under electric poten tial as low as 5 V mm−1, whose magnitude was three orders smaller than typical values of conventional LCDs. However, the response rate of GO LCDs was slow, and it took a long time to relax to an isotropic phase. Another concern was the chemical stability of GO, as the 2D flakes would undergo electrochemical corrosion and thermal reduction, both of which could degrade the optical performances.

sections.heading: 5.2. Magnetic LCs
sections.text:
LCs sensitive to magnetic field were also realized based on the anisotropy of magnetic susceptibility of molecules.[206] How ever, the relatively low magnetic susceptibility of small mole cules limited the further advancement to practical LCDs. Direct incorporation of magnetic colloidal nanomaterials into LCs as either guest constituents or building blocks was later found to be a promising approach toward magnetically responsive
Adv. Mater. 2019, 1807061
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1807061 (25 of 33)
LCs.[207] For example, iron oxide nanorods with high aspect ratios and ferrimagnetic property exhibited instantaneous alignment parallel to the direction of the magnetic field due to their strong magnetic anisotropy.[208] Relying on that, a fast magnetooptical switching LCs was designed in the aqueous dispersion of magnetic nanorods, with working principle illus trated in Figure 18a. The Fe3O4@SiO2 nanorods were 1.5 µm in length and showed uniform orientational order under mag netic field (Figure 18b,c). For investigating the magnetoop tical switching, colloidal dispersion of nanorods was placed between polarizer and analyzer with orthogonal transmission axis. When the direction of the external magnetic field was par allel or perpendicular to the transmission axes of the polarizer, the transmittance approached zero as evidenced by polarized optical microscopy (POM) in Figure 18d–g. When θ was 45°, as predicted by Equation (19), the transmittance approached max imum, resulting in brightest view under POM. In combination with lithography, the orientational order of nanorodbased LCs can be readily fixed in polymer matrixes. As shown in Figure 18h–j, thin films with predesigned patterns were pro duced by sequential magnetic alignment and photoinitiated polymerization. Switching the transmission axes of polarizer and analyzer by 45° simultaneously generated a reverse pattern due to the exchange of phase angles between nanorods in the two contrast areas.

sections.heading: 6. Responsive Luminescence and Raman Emission
sections.text: In luminescence and Raman emission, electrons in molecules or nanomaterials are excited to highenergy states upon light excitation, and photons are reemitted when relaxing back to their ground states. The photon–electron interactions fre quently couple with their chemical surroundings or the crystal lographic symmetry of the emissive nanocrystals via electron or energytransfer processes, which gives rise to various remark able optical phenomena, like polarized emission, fluorescence quenching and enhancing effects, as well as surfaceenhanced Raman scattering (SERS). With those wellestablished prin ciples, three practical approaches have generally been devel oped: tuning the orientation of anisotropic emitters, tuning the separation and chemical surroundings for responsive fluores cence, and Raman scattering. In this subtopic discussion, we first introduce the responsive photoluminescent nanomaterials (RPLs), followed by an overview of recent progresses in active SERS for sensing and detections.

sections.heading: 6.1.1. Electric RPLs Based on Perturbation to Orientation
sections.text:
Polarized photoluminescence from anisotropic emitters, like quantum rods,[209] semiconductor nanowires,[210] and organic dyes,[211] provides additional freedom and sensitivity for responsive optics. They are wellunderstood within several reported mechanisms, like the quantum size effect, electric field confinement, asymmetric chemical environments. Rare earth phosphors have been investigated intensively for their abundant energy levels, multiple transitions, and sublevel degenerations in both photon upconversion and downconver sion systems.[212] Each emission from the corresponding sub level transition is polarized along specific direction depending on the crystallographic symmetry. Therefore, the photolumi nescence spectra of lanthanide ions in crystalline host matrix feature multiple emission peaks, whose line profiles are respon sive to the orientation of nanoemitters.[213] By assembling the nanorods in LC cells, the orientation, as well as optical emis sion, could be regulated by an electric field. The specific align ment of nanorods within liquid crystals was evidenced by the
Adv. Mater. 2019, 1807061
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1807061 (26 of 33)
optical transmission microscopy images (Figure 19a). Without an electric field, transverse collective orientations of nanorods due to capillary invasion gave rise to bright transmission under two orthogonal polarizers. By contrast, the resulted homeo tropic orientations under electric field exhibited entirely black due to the vanishing of birefringence. The detailed three con figurations for acquiring the emission spectra were depicted in Figure 19b. The blue and red curves were obtained under trans verse configuration with a polarizer perpendicular and parallel to the orientation of nanorods, respectively. Consequently, the spectrum σ was a superposition of longitudinal magnetic dipole transition and transverse electric dipole transition. In the case of spectrum π, however, the situation was the oppo site (Figure 19c). The difference between their emission pro files was originating from the independent polarization of each sublevel emission due to the crystalfield splitting.[214] In addi tion to the electric field, the collective orientation of LaPO4:Eu nanorods was sensitive to the shear flow in the capillary. As depicted in Figure 19d, nanorods were highly orientated near the wall, with a tendency to align their long axis parallel to flow direction, due to the strong shear stress and disordered in the center where both gradient of flow velocity and resulted stress approached zero. The increase of order parameters in high flow rate was directly visualized in the POM images in Figure 19e, which suggested a clear flow birefringence and high transmis sion. Figure 19f shows the corresponding response of polar ized photoluminescence spectra to flow rate with a polarizer perpendicular to the flow direction. In principle, higher order induced by faster flow could suppress the transverse magnetic dipole transition but enhance the longitudinal magnetic dipole transition

sections.heading: 6.1.2. Chemical RPLs Based on Perturbation to Chemical Surrounding
sections.text:
QDs are well known for their unique sizedependent optical and electronic properties, particularly the luminescence excited by light at a specific wavelength. Due to the quantum confine ment effect, photoexcitation generates electron–hole pairs and emit light at a longer wavelength when subsequent recombina tion occurs.[215] Since the first discovery in the early 1980s,[216] various physical, chemical, and biological synthesis methods have been developed for precise size control and fine tailoring of their sizedependent excitation and emission spectra.[217] More importantly, it is found that the excitationemission is quite sensitive to the chemical surroundings, where they are either enhanced or quenched by photoinduced electron or energytransfer processes in QDs–molecules conjugates,[218] assemblies,[219] and hybrid nanostructures.[220] Therefore, var ious types of chemically responsive fluorescent nanostructures have been reported for sensors,[221] biological detectors,[222] and probes.[223] For example, dumbbellshaped nanohybrids com posed of carbon QDs and Au nanoclusters were reported as an efficient ratiometric fluorescent probe for sensing cadmium (II) ions and lascorbic acid.[224] The blue emissive carbon

sections.heading: 6.2. Responsive Raman Scattering Based on Nanomaterials
sections.text:
Since the elastic Rayleigh scattering most invariably dominates the photon–electron interactions, the energy shifts of photons between excitation and emission in Raman scattering occur with low probabilities in quantum mechanics. Consequently, the scattering crosssections (10−16–10−11 nm2 per molecule) of Raman scattering, as well as the optical intensities, are typically
small.[225] SERS was first recognized during the study of the role of absorption at Ag electrodes in 1974.[226] Further studies revealed that the enhancement factor could be more than 106 when the Raman molecules were incorporated into plasmonic nanostructures.[227] The enhancement originates from the inter ference between electromagnetic enhancement in plasmonic resonance and photon–electron interactions in Raman scat tering. So far, tuning the interparticle separation of plasmonic assemblies is most intensively exploited for responsive SERS. The Raman enhancement increases exponentially, as the gap distance becomes smaller than particle size. Generally, respon sive SERS can be categorized into two types: tunable separation in substrates, like polymer matrices, or through specific chem ical or physical processes in a colloidal dispersion and tuning the chemical surroundings.

sections.heading: 6.2.1. SERS Based on Perturbation to Separation
sections.text:
Incorporation of plasmonic nanomaterials into elastomeric substrates provides straightforward, quantitative, and revers ible plasmonic coupling for SERS. The feasible control over the deformation facilitates not only the quantification of correla tion between interparticle separation and enhancement factor but also precise detection of chemical species. Recently, SERS

More often, plasmonic nanostructures carrying responsive SERS were realized in assemblies of plasmonic colloids in dispersions. The involved chemical and physical processes include specific bonding between DNA strands,[229] chelation,[230] responsive swellingdeswelling of polymers,[231] tunable electrostatic inter actions,[232] and hydrogen bonding.[233] By taking advantages of the chelation between Cd2+ and ligands modified on the surface of Au nanoparticles, highly sensitive and selective SERS sensor was reported.[230] Through the chelation between Cd2+ and surface ligands, aggregation of Au nanoparticles occurred and the continuous redshift of a new peak in the extinction spectra indicated the presence of strong plasmonic coupling. Conse quently, a dramatic linear increase in Raman intensity with a sensitivity of 120 µm−1 was observed, which was comparable to the fluorescence sensor.[234]

sections.heading: 6.2.2. SERS Based on Perturbation to Chemical Surrounding
sections.text: In addition to electromagnetic enhancement, the charge transfer effect is another mechanism proposed for SERS. The energy difference between Fermi level of metal materials and molecular orbitals of Raman dyes play a key role in the charge transfer resonance. When it is comparable with the energy of the excitation laser, the induced charge transfer gives rise to a strong enhancement in Raman signals.[235] In combination with the high sensitivity of Raman transitions to the polarizability of molecules, Raman signals can respond to the chemical sur roundings through the intermolecule interactions. For example, enantioselective discrimination by SERS spectra was realized by taking advantage of intermolecule hydrogen bonding and charge transfer enhancement.[233a] The probe molecule, para mercaptopyridine, was covalently connected to Ag nanoparticles through SAg bonds, which exerted a redshift of the absorp tion peak of Ag nanoparticles (Figure 20c). The fabricated SERS probe was then immersed into various chiral molecules in enan tiomers of various types of alcohols. In the case of 2butanol (Figure 20d), a distinct decrease in the intensity at 1578 cm−1 and a simultaneous increase in intensity at 1612 cm−1 occurred when the probe interacted with S enantiomer or in the racemic mixture. So was the intensity ratio between bands at 1220 and 1202 cm−1. The protonation of the terminal nitrogen atom in the probe molecules when interacting with different enantiomers through hydrogen bonding was proposed for understanding the SERS enantioselective discrimination behavior. The protonation caused orientation differences between the complexes relative to the Ag surface and different energy states, which induced differ entiated charge transfer processes between probe molecules and Ag nanoparticles and intensity distinction in SERS spectra.[236]

sections.heading: 7. Conclusions and Perspectives
sections.text:
Herein, we have summarized the fundamental principles and new developments in the design and fabrication of responsive
optical nanomaterials. At the beginning of each section, the fundamental theory and equations are provided as the basic guideline toward practical strategies for realizing optical switching. For example, although they are frequently modi fied by the structural complexity and geometrical asymmetry, Bragg’s law and its derivatives are broadly cited for quantita tively explaining the remarkable optical response upon external stimuli. From a practical point of view, active control over the diffraction in photonic crystals calls for either carefully manipu lating the dynamic equilibrium between short and longrange interactions or systematically engineering the inhomogeneous complex structures of photonic components and responsive components. The former ones give rise to instant yet reversible peak shifts as well as dramatic color changes, originating from the dynamic equilibrium of the structures, which makes them ideal for inkfree printing. The later ones feature steady and desirable optical responses to mechanical, chemical, thermal, or optical stimuli, with practical potentials being widely demon strated in sensors and anticounterfeiting devices.
When light of a certain region of the spectrum is absorbed, then the nanomaterials will appear to be the complementary color. As a result, the operating colloidal concentrations are generally lower to achieve bright and obvious color transitions compared with photonic crystals, which span a broad range of volume fractions from 1D nanochains (below 5%), 3D dense photonic crystals (≈30%) to closepacking in CCAs (74%). The four working principles in responsive plasmonics have been demonstrated with intrinsic advantages and limitations. In the case of tuning the chemical surroundings, they have been intensively exploited in the refractive index sensors. Tuning the orientation of anisotropic plasmonic nanostructures gives rise to continuous tunability between two extreme excitation states. Accordingly, their colors and spectral profiles switch reversibly between two typical states. By contrast, assembly of plasmonic nanoparticles results in broad tunability in their plasmonic resonance and perceived colors in a colloidal dispersion. How ever, suffering from the poorly assembled structures and asso ciated multiple resonance modes, the colors are not brilliant. Also, the high sensitivity to temperature or ionic strength of the assembly process limits their optical responses to specific applications. By tuning the dielectric properties of plasmonic nanostructures through morphological reconstruction, excita tion of interband transitions and tunneling effects have been proven to be the new approaches toward responsive optics. Practically, they have been used in plasmonic laser printing and ultrafast optical signaling, both of which, however, require high orientational or positional order of anisotropic plasmonic nanostructures. As new types of color switching systems, the redox reactions of dyes or inorganic transition metal oxides have been reported as rewritable papers and smart windows. Whereas the simple twostate transitions powered by electric field or light provide feasibility for routine printing and reading, their optical response and printing cycles are well established by tailoring the catalytic performance of nanomaterials or redox properties of dyes/pigments.
Our discussion further covers the research achievements in responsive liquid crystals and luminescent nanomaterials. The early interest in the liquid crystal phase of anisotropic nanostructures stemmed from carbon nanomaterials due to

Adv. Mater. 2019, 1807061
their high aspect ratio and considerably small features. The abundant surface charges and associated electrical double layers around carbon nanostructures render them higher sensitivity to applied electric potentials, which reduces the power consump tion by several orders compared with conventional LCs. The introduction of nanomaterials into liquid crystals also makes it more flexible to induce responses to external stimuli. For example, the nematic phase was reported in magnetic nanorods under the external magnetic field. The optical switching fre quency under alternating magnetic field was comparable to commercial LCs. The contactless and instantaneous magnetic interactions also facilitate practical applications (displays, optical actuators, and waveguides) in combination with their enhanced compatibility to conventional fabrication processes, e.g., photolithography. Several issues, however, have hindered the advancements to commercial applications, including low relaxation rate, poor electrochemical stability, and longterm colloidal dispersibility of nanostructures. Responsive photolu minescent nanostructures covering a range of materials with active emission and scattering to external stimuli are discussed as well. With their advantages of supernarrow peak profiles, strong emission, and wellestablished excitationemission cor relation, photoluminescent nanostructures are more promising as responsive platforms for chemical, biological sensors, and detectors compared with previous three responsive systems.
The past three decades have witnessed significant pro gress in responsive optical nanomaterials, including both the development of conceptually novel sensitive materials and the advancements of existing platforms to solve practical problems. Regarding the responsive photonic nanostructures, the chal lenges in fundamental research lie in the assembly of aniso tropic building blocks into RPCs and exploration of new optical opportunities. We have demonstrated the unique optical tun ability by varying the direction of the magnetic field instead of strength when ellipsoidal nanoparticles were magneti cally assembled into 3D photonic crystals. More generally, the symmetrybreaking in shapes of nanomaterials gives rise to magnetic anisotropy, whose easy axis will in turn couple with the shape anisotropy, forming photonic crystals with unique structural complexity and diversity. These, however, call for synthesis approaches toward highly uniform anisotropic nano materials with a suitable size between 100 and 500 nm. The requirements of monodispersity of anisotropic building blocks are much higher than the case of nanospheres, since any size and shape variance could ruin the structural uniformity and degrade the optical performance. From the practical point of view, the challenges come from the largescale synthesis of colloidal building blocks as well as their robust assembly into highquality photonic crystals. We believe that the develop ments in colloidal synthesis and everincreasing research inter ests in RPCs will rapidly drive their commercialization to meet the strong market demands in specific areas, such as pressure sensors and photonic inks, papers.
The main challenges in responsive plasmonics are the con trollable assembly of metallic nanoparticles into welldefined structures and tunable excitation of their plasmonic reso nance. To this end, several approaches have been developed for the assembly of plasmonic nanoparticles into either 1D or branched chains. For example, relying on DNA,[237] hard
templates,[238] and molecular clusters,[239] nanoparticles can be well organized into predesigned structures. By controlling the electrostatic interactions via ionic strength,[162] temperature,[161] and solvents,[240] metallic nanoparticles selfassembled into branched chainlike structures with continuously shifted plas monic coupling. Coupled magnetic and plasmonic nanostruc tures are promising units for constructing responsive materials. Even though assembly approaches toward magnetoplasmonic nanostructures have been reported, it is still highly desirable to develop colloidal synthesis approaches that are compatible with conventional wetchemistry methods, like templated syn thesis or liganddirected growth of metallic nanomaterials. To achieve this goal, we have outlined several criteria based on the previous research efforts, including comparable small features to minimize resonant scattering, feasible control over the size and shape, strong magnetic susceptibility for assembly or ori entation control by an external field, and enhanced stability and dispersibility of colloidal nanocomposites.
Coupling shape and property anisotropy of nanostructures to fluorescent and Raman molecules and particles is a promising approach toward orientationsensitive optical nanomaterials. Generally, the enhancement of Raman scattering or fluores cence is highly related to localized electric fields around plas monic nanostructures. Therefore, the optical signals, as well as spectral profiles of such nanocomposites, are responsive to their orientation regulated by external stimuli. In reality, the angledependent Raman scattering has been demonstrated based on Ag nanorod array, whose orientation was uniformly tilted by 73°.[241] The SERS signals were found to be highly sen sitive to the incident angle of excitation light and approached maximum when it was 45° relative to the surface normal. How ever, Raman scattering responsive to the structural orientation is rarely reported, since it requires multifunctional nanostruc tures that feature both strong plasmonic resonance and mag netic anisotropy for orientational control.
Mentioned above are only representative examples of unlim ited research opportunities that are and will be exploited in the communities of responsive optical nanomaterials. By taking advantages of colloidal synthesis and interface chemistry, one would be able to overcome the majority of existing challenges soon and establish emerging optical nanostructures with smart response to external stimuli. Also, it is exciting that sev eral techniques described in this review are expected to actu ally benefit our daily life soon, especially in the field of smart windows, rewritable papers, pressure sensors, and biological imaging and detections. Given the importance of responsive optical nanostructures in today’s world, we need collaborative innovation from different research communities to create next generation smart nanomaterials that can subtly respond to the environment in many realworld applications.

metadata.abstractText: DOI: 10.1002/adma.201807061 Nanomaterials are materials with one or more dimensions falling into the nano­ meter scale. The dramatic size shrinkage renders them new electronic, magnetic, optical, and thermoelectric properties, which are not achievable by their bulk counterparts. It is widely accepted that the quantum confinement of electrons within potential walls created by nanoscale struc­ tures is responsible for the novel proper­ ties associated with the various types of solid­state nanomaterials. One of the most successful examples is provided by semi­ conductor quantum dots (QDs) whose sizes are typically within several nano­ meters. With strong size­dependent spectral properties and narrow emis­ sion, QDs have achieved great success in applications such as biological imaging, catalysis, and sensing. More generally, substantial progress has been made to synthesize or fabricate nanomaterials using either top­down and bottom­up methods, providing enormous opportu­ nities for tailoring their dimension, mor­ phology, and chemical composition with nanometer precision. In addition, the advancement of charac­ terization techniques has clearly revealed the dependence of chemical and physical properties of solid­state nanomaterials on their structural details. Responsive optical nanomaterials are materials that can dis­ play optical changes in response to external stimuli. Over the past three decades, many research efforts have been devoted to developing smart optical nanomaterials that can sense and actively respond to external physical and chemical per­ turbations. The mostly explored responsive optical systems are built based on photonic crystals (PCs), which are periodi­ cally arranged dielectric materials with widely tunable optical properties. Due to the constructive and destructive interference of light by the periodic microstructures, they can efficiently diffract light, with the wavelength determined by the dielectric constants of the constituents and their spatial arrangement.[1] Various smart optical materials could, therefore, be estab­ lished by incorporating stimuli­responsive components into the photonic crystal lattice to alter either the dielectric con­ stants or the lattice structures. With a better understanding of photon–matter interactions and the significant progress in microfabrication techniques, the photonic crystal struc­ tures, as well as optical manipulation methods, have been greatly diversified, leading to the successful development of many high­performance sensors, detectors, displays, etc. The advances in the synthesis of colloidal nanomaterials, beginning Responsive optical nanomaterials that can sense and translate various external stimuli into optical signals, in the forms of observable changes in appearance and variations in spectral line shapes, are among the most active research topics in nanooptics. They are intensively exploited within the regimes of the four classic optical phenomena—diffraction in photonic crystals, absorption of plasmonic nanostructures, as well as color-switching systems, refraction of assembled birefringent nanostructures, and emission of photoluminescent nanomaterials and molecules. Herein, a comprehensive review of these research activities regarding the fundamental principles and practical strategies is provided. Starting with an overview of their substantial developments during the latest three decades, each subtopic discussion is led with fundamental theories that delineate the correlation between nanostructures and optical properties and the delicate research strategies are elaborated with specific attention focused on working principles and optical performances. The unique advantages and inherent limitations of each responsive optical nanoscale platform are summarized, accompanied by empirical criteria that should be met and perspectives on research opportunities where the developments of next-generation responsive optical nanomaterials might be directed.
